Zhang Maozhong An MIIT Key Laboratory of Critical Materials Technology for New Energy Conversion and Storage, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin Technology, Harbin 150001, Heilongjiang, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The characteristics of electrodeposition and recent transition metal-based catalysts synthesized by electrodeposition are reviewed comprehensively, which guide for developing advanced electrodeposition technology and preparing new generation catalysts to achieve efficient hydrogen production via water splitting. Developing lower-cost and higher-effective catalyst to support hydrogen (H2) production by electrochemical water-splitting has been recognized as a preferred strategy to drive the clean energy utilization. As a credible technology for the synthesis of functional materials, electrodeposition has attracted widespread attention, especially suitable for non-noble transition metal-based catalysts (TMCs). Recently, lots of researchers have been devoted to this hot research direction with plentiful achievements, however, a comprehensive review towards this area is still missing. Hence, we summarize the past research progress, presents the technical characteristics of electrodeposition from the viewpoint of fundamental theory and influence factors for the electrochemical deposition behavior, and introduce its application in various of TMCs with versatile nanostructures and compositions. Except a deeper and more comprehensive cognition of electrodeposition, we further discuss the catalyst's optimized hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) performance as well as overall water splitting that combined with the synthetic process. Finally, we conclude the technical advantages towards electrodeposition, propose challenge and future research directions in this promising field. This timely review aims to promote a deeper understanding of effective catalysts obtained via electrodeposition strategy, and provide new guidance for the design and synthesis of future catalysts for hydrogen production. Keywords Electrodeposition Transition metal-based catalysts Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Water splitting 1 Introduction Traditional fossil fuel has played a crucial role in the historical development of whatever the energy conversion [1–5]. However, under the new background of increasing energy demand (nearly 20 Terawatt in 2020) and fossil fuel depletion due to overdependence in the 21st century, it is necessary to explore sustainable strategies for the wide application of new-type energy which guarantee both high energy density and environmental friendliness [6–8]. In such circumstances, suitable substitute has emerged in endless stream such as nuclear energy, wind energy, biopower and especially hydrogen energy, which is widely believed that has promised application value for the characteristics of gravimetric energy density, ample reserves and environmental benignity [9]. Over the past few years, variety of production technologies have been developed for water molecular splitting and release hydrogen (H2). Attractively, electrocatalytic water molecular splitting strategy has gotten the most in-depth study whether from catalyst or overall hydrogen production system [10–13]. Based on the electrical driving and assisted by highly active catalysts, water splitting process consists of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on the cathode and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) on the anode [14–16]. As the core part, although with difference source in acid or neutral/alkaline, the mechanism of HER can be classified into two parts as follows: Volmer step for electron transfer and the transformation of intermediates which followed by Heyrovsky step or Tafel step for the hydrogen generation [17]. Compared with HER, the four-electron transfer steps of OER process is more complex in different pH solution. By consisting of the above two parts, the overall water splitting process with a thermal free energy ΔG° = +237.2 kJ mol−1 requires a thermodynamic voltage of 1.23 V (vs. RHE) to drive this reaction. Restricted by the reaction barrier, load transfer resistance and the interface resistance cannot be completely eliminated, these force a higher working voltage to overcome the sluggish reaction kinetics [18–20]. Hence, suitable HER and OER catalysts to assist in low energy H2 production are essential [21,22]. Not only need to ensure the active site density as well as low enough charge transfer resistance of the material, Sabatier principle points out that in HER, the optimum electron density is critical to directly contribute to the moderate bonding strength with adsorbed H immediate, and analogous theory also be suitable for OER [23–25]. Combined with the reaction mechanism and all-sided evaluation criteria analysis (Overpotential, Exchange Current Density, Tafel Slope, Turnover Frequency, Faraday Efficiency, Electrochemically Active Surface Area and Stability), the HER and OER performance can be theoretically and experimentally determined [4,12,15]. Based on these, it is more liable to ensure the low unit energy cost and the popularization of technology for the goal of large-scale H2 production by the assistance of ideal-type catalysts. Nowadays, a wide variety of metal-based compounds as a reliability HER catalyst have been verified in acidic, neutral and alkaline solution. Based on the d-band theory for HER, noble metal-based catalysts (Pt, Ru, Pd, Ir, etc.) catalysts have been recognized owing supreme activity, but greatly hindered by their high costs and weak stability [19,26,27]. Thereby, switching to cheap alternatives with a lower per unit energy cost is the way out for global-scale implementation. Benefiting from unique electron distribution and earth-abundant material, different families of transition metal-based materials (Ni, Co, Mo, V, Fe, Mn, etc.) have attracted tremendous attention for the synthesis of advanced catalyst [28–30]. Not only can they exhibit Pt-like HER activity, more kinds of nonprecious metal-based catalysts has OER activity to achieve the bifunctional performance especially in alkaline solution (the alkaline system is designed to satisfy the four-electron reaction kinetics over OER process), which provide a brighter application prospect from the optimization of energy-utilization efficiency [20,31–33]. Over the past decade, deeper cognition of reaction mechanism and powerful nanotechnology together direct us to achieve the design of catalysts with good composition and structure, and catalyst has been imparted better electrochemical activity and long-term working stability. Specifically, excellent electrocatalysis activity is closely related to the constitute and structure which universally listed as follows with their characteristics. We follow with a brief overview of common synthetic strategies: (1) Wet chemical strategy: Chemical oxidation-reduction strategy is an universal method to synthesize metal-based compounds [34–37]. Electroless deposition has been evolved though the combination of self-supporting substrate and the in-situ chemical oxidation-reduction process [38]. Under extreme temperature, the reaction thermodynamic barrier is easily to break, and hydro-solvothermal strategy has been exploited which becomes a versatile route for the preparation of transition metal compounds with nanosheets, nanorods or pluralistic nanocrystals, core-shell structure, etc, as well as multivariate composition and non-metallic matrix composites in most case [39–43]. It also controls the growth and transformation process flexibly, manipulate crystalline state and morphology which consequently determines the catalysis performance [40,44–46]. Nevertheless, the reunion caused during the violent reaction is unavoidable that affect the catalytic activity negatively, and the reaction process also along with uncertainty, which result in the difficulty for ensuring the repeatability of product synthesis [39]. These intrinsic defects are difficult to remove by simple adjustment. (2) Solid-phase strategy: Anneal is an ancient technology for material handling, and on this basis, it has been constantly embellished for a wider use by the further expansion technology. The usual process of solid-phase reaction are as follows: the precursor directly undergoes the high temperature calcination with a stable gaseous reactant or mixed extra solid reactants. It is also a simple approach for the flexible preparation of catalysts with crystalline oxides, phosphates, chalcogenides, nitride and borides [47–49]. As a considerable approach, better energy efficiency as well as improving overall safety in the process of material synthesis is the key to further application. (3) Physical/Chemical vapor deposition and atomic layer deposition: Traced back to the 1960s of the solid-gas reaction on the heated surface, it gradually optimized the process evolved into chemical vapor deposition (CVD), which have also been reported for the formation coatings, powders, fibers and monolithic components with accurate atomic regulation [50–53]. Like CVD, the physical vapor deposition (PVD) was also adopted, and atomic layer deposition (ALD) evolved with the innovation of nanomaterials synthesis [54,55]. As a potential technology for future nano-level synthesis undoubtedly, the complex process brings not only opportunity but also challenge, hence more efforts have to do to break the technical bottleneck for the broader popularity. In contrast to the above strategy, a unique technology that based on electrochemical mechanism deserves attention. The electrochemical techniques, which originated in the 19th century, is a breakthrough that combined the movement of electric charge with the transformation of chemical energy. It consists of reduction reaction at the cathode and the oxidation reaction at the anode carried out under the condition of charge transfer driven by the applied electric energy, which is analogous to a galvanic cell acting in reverse. Not only an effective analytical approaches for evaluating the performance of electrode materials, it has gradually refined into an alternative material synthesis technique, named as electrodeposition [56,57]. Driven by the load electricity, electrodeposition is a noteworthy technology that has fast real-time response, which can realize low-cost, environmental protection as well as mildness of reaction in the synthesis of materials [58,59]. Various factors work together with excellent technical flexibility for determines its excellent technical flexibility, which is particularly critical for the preparation of functional materials. Different from the abovementioned strategy, especially in the preparation of self-supporting catalysts, electrodeposition can achieve uniform and powerful growth in a short time, avoiding the side effects of adhesives, reducing electron transfer resistance and improving working stability, which are especially important to stimulate the potential of catalytic performance [39,60]. By changing the composition of the electrolyte and simple technique craft adjustment, electrodeposition has the ability to get the optimized compounds with desired nano-architecture and composition, which cater to the trend of simple strategies to develop new nanofunctional materials. Of note, amorphous compounds can be easily synthesized through electrodeposition, and full characterization analysis confirms the enrichment defects that result in the increasing active sites as well as unique electronic structures, resulting in a qualitative improvement in the catalytic performance of materials [61,62]. In addition to synthesize catalysts by one-step electrodeposition, many studies involve the synthesis or modification of precursors by electrodeposition. Through the combination with other synthesis technologies, the catalyst preparation strategy is greatly enriched, and the catalyst can be given more outstanding performance [63–65]. Towards water splitting, most significant reviews have focused on electrocatalyst with multitudinous synthesis methods recently, but lack all-side generalize on electrodeposition exclusively. Encouraged by the above of great recognition, we therefore summarize the contribution of electrodeposition in the synthesis of low-cost metal-based catalysts. Pointed at the integrated electrodeposition system, we firstly introduce the core technological characteristics from several aspects (including depositional mode, electrolyte, substrate, etc.). Then recent progress of representative works by electrodeposition are listed with analyzation dialectically (alloys, oxides/hydroxides, sulfide, selenide, phosphides, borates). Finally, we discuss the current challenges in the field of electrodeposition strategy followed by future vision towards electrocatalytic hydrogen production. By virtue of the prominent technology preponderance, this review is intended to provide technical support for advanced multifunctional catalysts design. 2 Turning electrodeposition craft in the catalyst synthesis process As a historical synthesis technology, electrodeposition system has been evolving for catering the multidimensional requirements of material. It is undisputed that the excellent electrocatalysis performance is closely bound up with tailored microstructure as well as composition, and these designations can be achieved by the optimized electrodeposition craft. For the preparation of catalysts, various factors have impact on the properties of coating, and flexible amendment craft is critical to achieve oriented functionalization of materials. Herein, we introduce the determinants of electrodeposition in detail, and ways how to adopt an optimal craft to meet the requirements of catalysts (Fig. 1 ). 2.1 Electricity input mode With the external assistance of charge transfer and electric field forces, electrodeposition system operates along with the energy conversion (electrical energy ⇆ chemical energy), which play the core function. Nucleation and crystal nucleus growth process are the core steps of electrodeposition, which are directly related to the electricity input, and the interaction can be described by the Kelvin Eq. (1): (1) τ = 2 δ V / z e 0 | η | where τ, δ, η, V are denoted nucleus radius, surface energy, overpotential and atomic volume, respectively. A standard three-electrode system is usually used to carry the electrodeposition reaction. The target reaction operates at working electrode (WE)/electrolyte interface, and the pattern of charge transfer can be visualized in product [66,67]. In this section, an overview of electricity input mode is listed as follows, and Fig. 2 (a) shows the typical input pattern. 2.1.1 Potentiostatic and galvanostatic input As mature technology, potentiostatic and galvanostatic input are exerted to continuously maintain the voltage/current to drive the reaction. Potentiostatic electrodeposition refers to a specific response at a constant voltage, and commonly used for depositing pure phase coating in three-electrode system, which is the preferred to control physical and chemical properties of the coating accurately [68]. Due to the differences in the redox potentials of different metals/nonmetals, precise control of the working potential is critical. K. Mech et al. [69] reported the work on potentiostatic electrodeposition synthesis of Co-Pd catalyst, and they discussed the influence of deposited potential systemically. The XRD pattern of the deposited layer from −0.7 V to −1.0 V observed the attenuation of Co hexagonal phase characteristics and the promotion of Pd deposition, which was coincided with the increase in the Co:Pd atomic ratio. By comparison the tafel values of all the sample, Co-31.2Pd (with 31.2 at. % of Pd) that deposited at −1.0 V showed the highest HER activity, confirming the key role of balanced potential for the excellent catalytic performance of the co-deposition layer. Galvanostatic electrodeposition controls a constant charge during the formation of the coating [68]. Compared with the former, it consists of a two-electrode or three-electrode system, and the reaction mechanism is usually dynamic and complicated, thus more likely to endow the coating with a better functional performance [70–72]. It is clearly recognized that the current density directly regulates the nucleation process and reflects a strong regularity with the inherent catalytic activity of the deposited layer. Wang et al. reported a Ni-Mo catalyst via one-step electrodeposition, and discussed the influence of current density [73]. Clear to find in Fig. 2(b) that the increasing current density caused the growth of sediments into three dimensions with the controlled growth rate of nucleus and atomic ratios (Ni:Mo), leading to an enhancement in H2 production efficiency. The deposited potential/current density is directly relevanted to the morphology and composition, it also affects the deposited reaction rate, coating adhesion, and the stability of the electrolytic liquid system. A widely recognized point is that the adjustment of current density/voltage value is directly and sensitively correlated with the activity of catalyst. 2.1.2 Cyclic voltammetry By the current response to the dynamic voltages, CV curves are often served as defining reaction mechanism [73,74]. Generally, the reciprocating oxidation/reduction process under low current density is not conducive for depositing the coating with large loading [75]. However, some work has taken new path to achieve the mixed doping by the slow deposition/stripping behavior. Zhang et al. [76] prepared thin NiFe film that Fe was doped on Ni-pre by CV, and they also studied the reaction process during CV process. Zeng’s group reported a universal route for fabricating single-atom catalysts (SACs) by simple CV electrodeposition [27]. As shown in Fig. 2(c), the doping of various precious/non-precious catalysts were made by the cathode/anode CV process. HAADF-STEM images, normalized XANES and EXAFS proved the atomic successfully doping in different substrate, also with the reconstruction of the substrate and thus together enhanced catalytic activity. The above work exhibit the unique advantages of CV doping at the atomic level, which is worthy for the synthesis of monoatomic dispersion materials. 2.1.3 Pulse current/voltage input Periodical current/voltage exerted to the electrodeposition system has several characteristics, such yielding a more compact structure with the more nucleation [77,78]. Recently, much of the works have synthesized film by a set of pulse input and discussed the effects of pulsed sediments [79]. A. Sharma et al. [81] synthesized Sn nanorods assisted on the porous alumina template via varying current pulse electrodeposition with a frequency of 90 Hz (Fig. 2d), and recognized the critical role of the intermittent pulse in tight nucleus growth (template assistance, current, switching time). For the ascension of catalytic performance, the regulated pulse parameters can make material obtain controlled morphology and increased reactive sites. Allahyarzadeh’s group prepared Ni-W-Al2O3 nanocomposite coating by with 3 A dm−2 with a pulse frequency from 100 to 1300 Hz with 200 intervals, and atomic force microscope (AFM) characterization clearly recognized the positive correlation between the grain size of the deposited layer and the pulse frequency, which reflects the key role of frequency selection on the coating [80]. P. Sivasakhi et al. [82] deposited Ni-CeO2Gd on Cu foam with 10 Hz pulse at the current density of 4 A dm−2. The obtained film formed highly dispersed CeO2Gd-doped nanoparticles, optimizing the crystal state as well as the electronic environment. Tafel slope comparison with or without doping (102 and 143 mV dec−1) proved that the sluggish reaction kinetics was improved, which exhibited the advantage of pulse variation. Undoubtedly, pulsed deposition controls the growth behavior of the crystal nucleus through changes in frequency and current/voltage, which can affect the catalytic performance. Meanwhile, pulse input also can moderate diffusion resistance, control multivariate chemical composition, microstructure as well as mitigating the side reaction. 2.1.4 Other technical assistance Electrolyte agitation is significantly effective to weaken the influence of diffusion control by centrifugal force, thereby increasing the transfer rate of ions, improving the current efficiency, and also obtaining a smoother coating with more nucleation [66,84]. Su et al. [83] studied the effect of different stirring speeds on NiFe alloys. It can be confirmed that regardless of the high Ni or high Fe electrolyte, the increase in stirring speed (400–1200 rpm) has resulted in an increase in the iron content of the alloy, and the current efficiency increased in the deposition process. Moreover, some novel technologies have emerged unceasingly. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), Yao et al. [85] reported a hydrothermal electrodeposition technique to synthesize NiCoFeZn alloy film directly on Ni foam, providing much stronger bonding with the substrate as well as better crystallization. By the subsequent removal of template, the ternary NiCoFe-pre had a significantly increased surface area. With the phosphorylation and vulcanization, the self-supporting catalyst ultimately exhibited a strong bifunctional activity for overall water splitting (1.52 V at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH). Lighting-assisted technology also has been adopted widely for electrodeposition on semiconductor substrates. Teng et al. synthesized novel heterostructural MoS2/TiO2 nanotube arrays by lighting-assisted electrodeposition (Fig. 3b), and the additional light sources enhance the efficiency of charge transfer [86]. In addition, some work innovatively adopted physical support technologies such as force field assistance and ultrasonic assistance to directionally regulate the properties of the deposited products [87,88]. To sum up, the electrodeposition behavior that assisted by other technologies, can be optimized in specific system and deserves more attention [89]. 2.2 Electrolyte Except for some special molten salt systems, traditional solution contains solvents and solutes, and several adjustable parameters acting on the electrolyte will sweep the reaction directly [66,90,91]. The schematic diagram in Fig. 4 (a) shows the composition of the electrolytic liquid system. 2.2.1 Solvent Aqueous solution is the most widely used solvent in electrolyte and can meet the general requirements in electrodeposition. Most classical solution is obtained by salts dissolve in aqueous media, and the composition of metallic/nonmetallic compounds can be artificially design by the solute adjustment [92]. However, the narrow electrochemical windows and temperature windows of aqueous solution cannot fit the higher standards of material synthesis. In order to deposit target material, we have to turn our attention to discovery alternative solvents with ranged electrochemical window [93]. High-temperature molten salts generally depend on high temperature and heavy pressure that result in the application difficulty [91]. Benefited from environment-friendly and chemical and thermal stability (Fig. 4b), ionic liquids (ILs) are getting more and more attention as the alternative electrolytes recently, many pioneering work investigate them for the synthesis of binary/ternary alloy or compound, which all have considerable HER and OER activity [94–98]. Deep eutectic solvents (DES) with different coordination capabilities are also qualified solvents [99]. A mainstream direction of optimizing electrodeposition technology is that search for more solvents with outstanding physical and chemical properties, as well as an acceptable cost. 2.2.2 Solute All the electrochemical reactions use the anions and cations as reactant that hydrolysable salts dispersed in the solvent. It is rational that different ions participating in the reaction should be clarified by multivariate analysis and then specify the type of solute [100]. As shown in Fig. 4(c), the metallic coating of NiCo is usually crystalline, and amorphous coating with Mo-doping that formed by co-deposition is valid strategy to induce defects, which enhanced catalytic activity and also configure better electron interaction [101–103]. In particular, ion diffusion behavior will cause the concentration gradient, and therefore, the ion concentration should be adjusted according to local conditions, which will distinctively reflect in the deposited layer. For the purpose of obtaining nano-scale morphology to increase the catalytically active area, the concentration of solute is usually adjusted to a low level to enhance the diffusion control behavior of the deposit, thereby promoting catalytic activity [48,104]. Specially, mild reducing agent (NaBH4, NaH2PO2, thiourea, etc.) are usually selected for source of nonmetals in sedimentary layer, which also leads to complex chemical changes in the co-deposition behavior [105,106]. 2.2.3 Electrolyte additive and multiple regulatory factors The reaction barrier between different species cause the potential gap in certain co-deposition system, and as an essential addictive, complexant is equipped to shrink or eliminate the gap by the coordination [72,107]. Typically, both Mo-based alloy and W-based catalysts often have unique electronic environments and oxygen vacancies which thereby exhibit good OER and HER activity, and their alloy or compounds need the coordination of citrate to achieve co-deposition [108]. In Fig. 4(d), it also can preferentially select active growth sites by regulating the ligand number, consequently control the growth pattern of nucleation [90]. Additionally, ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) and 5, 5-dimethyl ethylenegluconylurea (DMH) are also used as common complexant in the synthesis of Ni, Co or Cu-based alloy. In order to improve the coating performance (flatness, crystalline state, hardness, etc.), the introduction of functional inorganic addictive (micro-nano particles of Al2O3, SiO2 etc.) and organic additive such as polyethyleneglycol (PEG), sodium dodecylbenzenesulphonic acid (SDSA) and saccharin, nicotinic acid (NA), can regulate the size of the crystal nucleus, suppress side effects or incorporate new components [109,110]. However, the application of the above additives is not common in the synthesis of catalysts. Electrolytes with the addition of LiCl have good conductivity, so the current efficiency in electrochemical reaction can be improved. Temperature control affects the thermodynamic characteristics of the reaction through external input of heat energy, which in turn promotes a higher reaction rate and energy conversion efficiency [101,107]. C. Lupi et al. [111] deposited NiCoW ternary film on aluminum net. They groped the law of the composition with different temperature, and found that the high temperature (60 ℃) is dominated by the deposition of NiCo, while also exhibit higher current efficiency and strengthened deposited coating on the substrate. Evidently, at room temperature (30 ℃) is more conducive to the increase of W content. Additionally, the pH of the electrolyte directly determines the type of reaction that occurs, controlling a specific pH value is crucial for obtaining the target product (the metal phase solid solution is easy to obtain under acidic conditions, and the formation of complex compounds is beneficial under alkaline conditions) [107]. C. Lupi et al. [111] studied the effect of electrolyte pH values (5, 6, 7, 8, 9) on the composition of the Ni-Co-W layer, and confirmed that the content of W atoms in the plating layer will increase significantly. To further, maintaining pH stability during the electrodeposition reaction is imperative for homogeneous coating. On the premise that no impurity atoms are introduced, both acid and alkali are used to pre-adjust to the specified pH condition, and buffer solvent are added to stabilize the pH change, like H3BO3. Last but not the least, length of time for electrodeposition determines the thickness of coating or the size of the nanostructure, and only a moderate amount can expose the most active sites for better catalysis activity [62,73,112]. 2.3 Substrate and template From the early research on the preparation of noble metal catalysts to the transition metal-based catalysts currently, self-support structrue has always been a common pursuit. Catalysts with nanoporous architectures can be fabricated by multi-dimensional substrate or template. In Fig. 5 (a), not only have traditional 2D substrates such as metal foils and fluorine-doped SnO2 (FTO) glass, many types of carbon-based substrates include carbon cloth (CC), carbon paper (CP), and nonprecious metal foam (Ni/Cu/Fe), all have high electrical conductivity as well as high abundant microporous leading to generate a larger specific surface area [61,64,113–115]. Alternatively, further work hammer on the substrate to grow the preset template. ZnO nanorods and porous oxides of silicon and aluminum are regarded as typical self-sacrifice template to grow nanoarray [58,116–118]. Dong et al. [119] have constructed nanoarray Ni(OH)2/NiMoOx by three steps in Fig. 5(b). Firstly, the ZnO template was firstly grown on the surface of nickel foam with high density by hydrothermal method, and then the NiMo-pre was covered by electrodeposition, finally removed the template by soaking with high concentration KOH solution. Thanks to the increase of specific surface area brought from the template, more active sites were involved in the catalytic reaction process, and the detemplating process yielded the mixed heterogeneous structure of crystal-amorphous, thus endowed the catalyst Pt-like activity. Micro/nano porous Al2O3 can be grown on the upper layer of aluminum plate by anodic oxidation, and can be qualified to synthesize highly dispersed structures with two-dimensional longitudinal growth of substrate in the process of electrodeposition [120,121]. Some works took PS microspheres attached to the nickel foam surface as template to embellish the structure (Fig. 5c), and the template could be completely removed by simple annealing [58]. Co-deposition with graphene as a template and other components can obtain a composite coating, with better load transfer ability and functional optimization [122]. In addition to hard template, soft template also assists in the process of catalyst synthesis, such as high internal phase emulsion (HIPE) [123,124]. Interestingly, some innovative work achieved the synthesis of nanoporous materials in aqueous solvent with the bubbles derived from dramatic hydrogen evolution reaction, enlightening us for the exploration of new-type template strategies [125,126]. Our group prepared honeycomb Cu nanocrystals on the substrate of Cu foil by an one-step rapid electrodeposition strategy with extremely high current density (1000 mA cm−2, 60 s), while also clarified the direct effect of the gradient change of current density on the three-dimensional shape [127]. Gyeong Ho Han et al. [128] synthesized CoMo nanorods via a low potential deposition (-2 V vs SCE, 1800 s). The formation of rod-like morphology of the coating was promoted by the vigorous hydrogen evolution as the bubble template, which endowed a large active area (771.6 mV cm−2) and determined the remarkable HER activity. Moreover, except for exposing more active area, there is a synergetic effect between suitable substrate or template and catalyst [129]. Dong’s group [130] fabricated the W-doped Ni-Co phosphides based on Ni foam by the electrodeposition of Co-W precursor on Ni foam and the subsequent phosphating. Extensive studies confirmed the bimetallic Ni-Co site together contribute to the HER activity. W-NiCoP had a low overpotential (29.6 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and the tafel slope (38 mV dec−1), exhibiting the optimized reaction kinetics. DFT calculations shows that the introduction of W is considered as a suitable binding energy site for hydrogen intermediates. More conveniently, some studies have used substrate as the metal source to synthetic the coating directly which also works as part of the self-supporting catalysts [131,132]. Niu et al. [130] synthesized FeS/NiFeOH, in which FeS nanosheets contribute to electrocatalytic activity and are used as a supporting material. After coordinating with the subsequent NiFe(OH) x by a spontaneous electrodeposition behavior, the heterogeneous catalyst delivered a lower overpotential, optimized quick reaction kinetics and well durability in alkaline solution. Owing to groundbreaking studies keep popping up, there are many characteristic advantages, whereas defects cannot be ignored such as difficulty replication and scalable production. In general, electrodeposition is considered to have undergone a complex dynamic process. It should be emphasized that multiple factors are not isolated, but interacting during the electrodeposition, and adjusting measures to local conditions with synergetic strategy is encouraged. 3 Metal-based catalysts prepared by electrodeposition for HER and OER So far, we have discussed the craft properties of electrodeposition. Various metal-based catalysts that are competent for HER and OER and bifunction, have made a great scientific stride in the last decade for efficient H2 production by overall water splitting. Here we highlight the recent remarkable work of transition metal-based catalysts (electrodeposition technology is adopted in the synthesis route), list the representative frontier work in Table 1 systematically, and deeply analyze the eletrocatalytic activity that contributed by electrodeposition synthesis strategy. 3.1 Pure metals and alloys Compared with the strategy of traditional melting precursors or liquid phase reduction of alloys, electrodeposition can reduce energy consumption, expand the scope of application (normal temperature, atmospheric pressure, and abundant metal salt reactants), and has more flexible phase conversion and entropy changes, which make it possible for the increased catalyst activity [133]. Towards the preparation of pure metal-based coating, electrodeposition technology can be realized easily with changeable crystalline state and nanostructure by introducing additives and switching the deposition mode. However, the non-expensive pure metal has an unsatisfactory electronic environment which results in too strong or too weak H adsorption energy, thereby the catalytic performance is very limited [134]. Differently, strong synergy between multi-metal atoms can tap the potential of catalytic activity, and alloys prepared by electrodeposition can satisfy the regulation of the electronic environment of the catalyst, which has received abundant attention. Despite of the major drawbacks of high price and poor stability, Pt-based catalysts are still recognized as the most popular HER catalyst. In the early stage, forming Pt-based alloy is the main strategy to decrease the cost and maintain activity [135,136]. Meanwhile, by electrodeposition, Pt coating and Pt-doping strategy with nanoscale structures or composition are feasible to contact with low-cost catalysts [137,138]. In Fig. 6 (a), Chen et al. [139] fabricated the copper–platinum nanowires (NWs) by electroplating platinum onto copper nanowires. The Cu NWs coating process is realized by −0.3 V vs. NHE electrodeposition in PtCl6 2− solution. The peculiar core–shell structure not only had potential activity towards HER in neutral solution, but also retained better conductivity as well as high transmittance (>80%) to replace indium tin oxide (ITO). Ring et al. [140] chose a different path to carry out in-situ Pt doping. In electrochemical system, Pt foil as the counter electrode was used to provide cation by the subsequent cathodic reduction reaction via CV, and continuous circulation propelled HER kinetics. Inspired by the Pt-like electron configuration, some type of transition metal-based alloy (Ni, Co, Mo, Fe, Zn, W, Cu et al.) have developed imperatively for the replacement of noble metal based alloys, while the rich composition maximizes the HER activity [141–145]. Hong et al. [146] prepared NiW alloy on Cu foil via co-electrodeposition as an alkaline HER catalyst. The morphologies of amorphous NiW film varied significantly with the change of W content, and NiW film drove 2 mA cm−2 with the overpotential of 122 mV, exhibiting best HER activity with a W content of 51% at molar ratio. Lu et al. [147] deposited NiMoCu coating on Ni foam from roasted nickel matte precursor in choline chloride (ChCl)-urea deep eutectic solvent (DES) (Fig. 6b). By means of CV curves and characterization, the deposition behavior of the coating was clarified with considerable performance of HER. Moreover, some self-assembled catalysts utilize the synergistic effect of the alloy with other phases to obtain enhanced HER activity. Niu et al. [148] carried out the growth of nanoplates (Ni(OH)2/NiAl on the surface of NiAl foil by dealloying NiAl foil in KOH, and further work in Fig. 6(c) that the additional deposited phase (NiMo or NiFe) endowed the catalyst with remarkable bifunctional activity. NiFe/Ni(OH)2/NiAl had the overpotentials of 315 mV at 100 mA cm−2, and NiMo/Ni(OH)2/NiAl also displayed excellent HER performance with a low overpotential of 78 mV at 10 mA cm−2. In spite of transition metal-based alloy and its derivative are cost-effective alternatives, their on-stream side reaction could break the stability of catalysts, and therefore, more attention has to place on surface modification by cladding structure, or the further conversion of alloys precursors. 3.2 Oxides and hydroxides Cobalt and nickel oxides are worth considering as water oxidation catalyst, because of their affordable price, tunable structure and unique electron state. Including single metal oxides, spinel oxides and perovskite oxides, directional designation and synthesis can be achieved through various method [15,149]. Using electrodeposition, transition metal-base oxides have the ability to overcome the sluggish kinetics by the surface amorphization [150–153]. Dau and co-workers prepared cobalt oxide films by electrodeposition and studied the cation distribution and bonding. The in-situ Co K-edge X-ray absorption spectra combined with electrochemical coulometry measurement together revealed that the dynamic mutual conversion of the three structural motifs corresponded to the mobility of Co2+/Co3+/Co4+ ions, and Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectra identify Co-Co and Co-O cross-linking changed under different potential (0.85 V, 1.05 V and 1.35 V). All these directly proved that the synthesized cobalt oxide had high redox activity and can store (or accumulate) oxidation equivalents [154,155]. Except for surface amorphization, the simple electrodeposition is also capable of doping heteroatoms to tune the active site and construct heterogeneous structures [156,157]. Dai’s team [158] reported a Ni-Co-Cr oxide/metal catalyst by right of a simple electrodeposition and subsequent reductive annealing, which exhibited promised activity in 1 M potassium phosphate solution for effective HER (198 mV at 100 cm−2), and analysis also revealed that strong affinity of Ni and Ni-O for H2O helped to facilitate H-O bond cleavage. Meanwhile, some electrodeposition techniques are involved in the synthesis of oxides, has assembled novel energy storage device by means of the water redox reaction of the material. Chen et al. [115] synthesized ultrathin cobalt oxides on the carbon cloth by a quick electrodeposition method with the following annealing treatment. In Fig. 7 (a), further analysis demonstrated that the strong interaction between Co3O4 film and carbon cloth disclosed by Fourier transform (FT) EXAFS spectra, together with the unsaturated electronic environment, has achieved excellent OER activity. Moreover, its application in flexible optoelectronics and the flexible Zn-air battery also displayed outstanding performance. The discharge voltage and charge voltage were 1.03 V and 1.95 V, respectively, with robust stabilities. The crystal transition metal-based hydroxides consist of positively charged brucite-like layers with an interlayer portion containing charge-balancing anions [159,160]. Lots of representative works have recognized that transition metal-based hydroxide could be used as a promising candidate for the unique redox characteristics, and the NiFe-hydroxides is one of the most representative candidates [48,153,161,162]. Further studies have reported the hydroxide renovate the reaction kinetics during the OER process [163], and DFT calculations proved that the incorporation of various metal can increase the active site as well as near-optimal OH adsorption energetics [159]. Unlike general method, amorphous hydroxides are more complex ionic layered materials which generate rapidly in nitrate solution by the electrodeposition, so has attracted much attention in recent years. Inspired by the redox behaviors in CV process, Zhang et al. [76] chose a stepwise strategy to deposited the NiFe film for investigating the catalytic performance of water oxidation (Fig. 7b), and provided a reference for other film electrocatalysts. Research proved that during the electro-oxidation process, amorphous transition metal hydroxide will improve HER and OER activity due to the increase of the number of oxygen vacancies, which provided inspiration for catalyst modification strategies. Furthermore, the remarkable HER performance of transition metal-based hydroxides/oxides also has been reported because of the improved Volmer step, which promote the dissociation of water and the production of hydrogen intermediates in alkaline and neutral solution [114,164–166]. Materials with a large number of H-adsorption sites and hydroxides/oxides can synergistically enhance HER activity as a whole. Zhang et al. [132] reported a novel approach to synthesis three-dimensional Ni(OH)2/MoS2 hybrid catalyst. The former growth of MoS2 on carbon cloth by hydrothermal treatment and the latter electrodeposition method to cover Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles. In 1 M KOH, it has high HER activity with low overpotential of 80 mV at 10 mA cm−2, tafel slope of 60 mV dec−1 and long-term stability. In order to deeper understand the synergistic effect, an in-depth study was investigated by DFT calculation. The reaction pathway includes Volmer step and Tafel step or Heyrovsky step, and it is clearly to find that Ni(OH)2/MoS2 had optimized free energy diagrams (0.05 eV for H-OH and −0.06 eV for H*). Likewise, Yang et al. [167] synthesized a hybrid nanoarray structure of V-doped CoP@a-CeO2 by modification of amorphous CeO2 (a-CeO2) on the V-CoP surface. As illustrated in Fig. 7(c), the electrodeposited a-CeO2 interacted a strong synergistic effect with V, optimizing the Gibbs free energy of H* adsorption energy on Co site and matched with the Bader charge analysis, which resulted in the superior HER performance (68 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and low tafel slope of 48.1 mV dec−1). It was matched with the electronic control results of bader diagram. Toward overall water splitting, transition metal-based oxides/hydroxides have excellent bifuntional catalysis undoubtly [168–171]. Zhao et al. [169] investigated both HER and OER performance of a series of Ni-based catalysts with Co, Fe doping. By electrodeposition, the synthesis could be adjusted to any atomic ratios, and systematic study showed in Fig. 8 that the Fe-doping coursed the electrons migration from the Ni/Co sites, which activated the electron affinity of the Ni/Co sites that beneficial to the absorption/adsorption of OOH intermediate in OER. In contrast, the doped Co has similar electronic effects on the Ni sites, resulting in a better HER performance. Based on the ratio of highest HER and OER activity, Ni0.9Co0.1O x H y and Ni0.8Co0.1Fe0.1O x H y were selected as cathode and anode, respectively, for integral water splitting in 1 M KOH, which had 1.58 V at 10 mA·cm−2 and 1.72 V at 50 mA·cm−2 with continuous operation of 50 h stability. Despite of prominent Janus activity of HER and OER in alkaline solution, defect cannot be ignored that transition metal-based hydroxides/oxides cannot stay stable in an acidic solution. In addition, electrodeposition technology also participates in the preparation of the precursor, especially for multicomponent hydroxides [172,173]. Liu et al. [174] first electrodeposited Co-Zn LDHs, and then conducted solid-phase phosphating to obtain Zn-CoP catalyst. Through the convenient doping method, the inactive Zn was introduced to regulate the d-band of Co, enhanced the reactivity and tuned the moderate H chemisorption strength, thus upgraded the HER performance in both acid and alkali solution. Equally, the strong urea oxidation reaction (UOR) activity of Zn-CoP enabled a two-electrode electrolyzer for high effective H2 production with low voltage of 1.38 V to offer 10 mA cm−2. On the whole, both transition-based oxides and hydroxides can effectively optimize the reaction kinetics, which show great potential in the increasingly mature field of bifunctional electrolytic water catalyst. In the meantime, the flexible modification based on the intrinsic activity of hydroxides/oxides has great research significance. 3.3 Chalcogenides In the past few years, transition metal-based chalcogenides (mainly sulfides and selenides) have provoked substantial attention in application to the HER and OER. Layered 1 T-MoS2 has been widely acknowledge that possesses metallic property for the advantages in electrocatalysis. Hinnemann et al. has proved the highly active edge states of MoS2 for HER, which guide posterity's work for tuning the structure of the edge sides or activate the basal planes [175]. By suitable electronic structures and intrinsic surface-state, the pyrite or marcasite structure of nonlayered M x S y (M: Mo, Fe, Co, Ni etc.) also has potential activity for water splitting [33]. Electrodeposition is a greener and milder method than conventional high-temperature sulfuration/selenization in terms of risk and toxicity, and has emerged as an alternative method to engineer undercoordinated electron distribution, which enable efficient activation of HER [176,177]. Generally, the deposition of metal compounds with thiosulfate as the sulfur source consists of two steps in Eqs. (2) and (3): (2) 2 S 2 O 3 2 - + 6 H + + 4 e → 2 S + 3 H 2 O (3) M x + + S + x e → MS Additionally, the deposition behavior with other sulfides (urea, various metal sulfides etc.) as sulfur sources is more complicated. Mabayoje and co-workers [61] deposited a thin α-MoS x film on glassy carbon (GC) substrate with different sulfur ratios, investigated the effect of electrolyte composition and deposition mode, and focused on the electrochemical evolution of hydrogen. In Fig. 9 , the CV cycles display a versatile reaction path caused by rich chemistry of thiomolybdate. The S/Mo ratio of product by cathode, anode and cycle voltammetry electrodeposition are 2, 4 and 6, respectively. Further XPS analysis reviewed that the elemental sulfur exists as anions with Mo, the ratio of bridging and terminal sulfur groups is dependent on the electrodeposition mode. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analysis confirmed the MoS6 has higher coordination number, providing evidence for the coordination environment. Based on the above analysis, the promising catalyst with the highest S/Mo ratio of 6 by anodic deposition, has superior HER performance, confirming the positive effect of high S/Mo ratio on activity. Towards OER, many studies have demonstrated that molybdenum-based sulfides are certainly undergo an inevitable oxidation to generate oxides/(oxy)hydroxides, so the strategy of endowing the catalysts bifunctionally is to dope with other elements or make the heterostructure [59,178]. Except MoS2, other transition metal-based sulfides catalysts are also deposited with considerable HER and OER performance [179–183]. Liu et al. [184] synthesized Ni-Co-S film on Cu foam as bifunctional catalyst, which afforded 10 mA cm−2 at the overpotential of 140 mV for HER, and 100 mA cm−2 at 363 mV for OER in 1 M KOH. For the regularity of compounds properties in the same family, transition metal-based selenides synthesized by electrodeposition also have received wide attention, like Co-Se, Ni-Se, NiCo-Se and NiCoFe-Se, etc. [64,185–189]. Taking selenite as source, the process of co-deposition with metal is similar to sulfide. Differently, selenides not only have good HER activity, but also generally tend to exhibit better OER performance [190]. Xu et al. [191] fabricated an amorphous cobalt oxide/cobalt selenide composite film (CoO x -CoSe) that deposited on Ni foam. CoO x had a considered synergistic effect with CoSe, which optimized both HER and OER performance. For OER in 1 M KOH, the janus catalyst can reach 100 mA cm−2 and 500 mA cm−2 only at overpotential of 300 mV and 380 mV, respectively, and the overpotentials of 90 mV to deliver 10 mA cm−2 for HER. Moreover, in alkaline overall water splitting system, it obtained 20 mA cm−2 at a cell voltage round 1.66 V, which become a promising alternative to noble metal-based catalysts. For sulfides and selenides, all these pioneering works prove their immense potential, and researchers have analyzed the factors for the excellent performance from electrodeposition as follows: 1) the synergistic effect between M (metal), M-O and M-S/Se, yield mild electronic environment; 2) Amorphous structures provide large active area; 3) the advantages of uniform compact adhesion, and good electrical connection by one-step electrodeposition. 3.4 Phosphides Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) used as electrocatalytic can be dated back to the late last century [29]. The strong electronegative phosphorous element is a suitable adsorption site for proton hydrogen, which also changes the cation electron environment. On account of the excellent electronic properties, polytrophic composition and nanostructure, TMPs have the ability to serve as efficient all-pH HER as well as bifuntional water splitting catalysis in alkaline solution [16,192]. Similar with sulfides, phosphides also have diversified composition and structures, such as the typical Ni-based phosphides, mainly consists of metal-rich Ni12P5, phosphorus-rich NiP3 and various metal/phosphorus stoichiometric ratios material [193,194]. Because of the difference constituent elements and stoichiometric ratios, which lead TMP with greater potential in catalyst activity [195]. The desirable strategy of electrodeposition has also been adopted in the synthetic of phosphide catalysts and submitted satisfactory answers in terms of HER and OER performance. The deposition process of metal phosphide with sodium hypophosphite as phosphorus source is shown in Eqs. (4), (5) and (6): (4) H 2 PO 2 - + 5 H + + 4 e → PH 3 + 2 H 2 O (5) H 2 PO 2 - + 2 H + + e → P + 2 H 2 O (6) M x + + P + x e → MP Burchardt et al. [196] studied the relationship between the crystal size of the deposited Ni3P and the HER activity, and recognized the synergetic properties of metal Ni and Ni-P. Inspired by the appreciably optimized composition and electron structure, researchers have hammer at form multiple metal phosphides. Xiao’s group [197] engineered a Ni-Co-P nanoparticles by introducing carbon nanotubes on Ni foam and electrodeposition. The good activity of low overpotential of 80 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH, stemmed mainly from the synergy between CNT and the dispersed NiCoP. Additionally, it also exhibited salient HER performance in 0.5 M H2SO4. Further work has proved that cationic cooperation strategy is also capable of the electrodeposited Ni-P catalysts with considerable OER performance [198]. In Fig. 10 (a), Kim et al. [199] introduced a Ni-Cu-P catalyst via one-step electrodeposition. The blending of Cu shifted in the surface electronic state and also made it more oxidation-resistive, improving the stability of electrooxidation process. Normalized polarization curves that Ni59Cu19P9 exhibited remarkable OER performance, and high-resolution XPS analyses observed the increase of the amount of NiOOH that credited for the OER activity of the catalyst. Except for Ni-based phosphides, the deposited Co-based phosphides have also been widely reported [200]. Saadi et al. [201] synthesized the Co-P film electrochemically, and evaluated for performance as a catalyst for the hydrogen evolution reaction. SEM displayed the distribution of clusters, and further spectroscopy characterization indicated that the coating consisted of metal cobalt, cobalt phosphide, various amorphous-oxide and orthophosphate. Inspired by above, the mixed phase of Co-P with 1:1 stoichiometric ratio, exhibited excellent HER activity than other ratio as well as other HER catalyst candidate (ηPt < ηCoP film ≤ ηCoP NP, ηNi2P < ηCoSe2 < ηMoS2 < ηMoSe2). Although many benefits can be found in one-step electrodeposition techniques, it has to be admitted that insufficient phosphorus in the deposited film has a great limit on the improvement of catalytic activity. Many studies have shifted to synthesize precursors by electrodeposition followed by phosphatize at high temperature, resulting in a leap in catalyst activity [48,113,130]. Sun and co-workers [113] fabricated Mn-doped CoP nanosheets on Ti-mesh as all-pH HER catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 10(b), the Mn-doped precursor was synthesized simply by electrodeposition and NaH2PO2 participated in the subsequent high temperature phosphating reaction. Comprehensive characterization and DFT calculations were common revealed that Mn doping induced more suitable H-adsorption free energy (ΔG H*), and therefore enhanced HER activity. In 0.5 M H2SO4, 1 M KOH and phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), Mn-CoP had an overpotential of 49 mV and 76 mV and 86 mV at 10 mA cm−2, respectively, which is lower than that without Mn. As the most powerful competitor of noble metal catalysts, it is worthwhile to put enough effort into the TMPs catalyst synthesis engineering by electrodeposition, and notably, controlling the proportion of phosphorus in electrodeposition behavior to influence the intrinsic activity and morphology of catalysts needs further study. 3.5 Borates Similar with TMPs, many studies have pointed that the catalysis enhancement of TMBs derived from electron-rich and highly electronegative boron atoms acts as an active HER site by altering the hydrogen binding energy, therefore transition metal-based borides have attracted tremendous attention in the last two decades [36,202]. At the same time, electrodeposition technology was rapidly popularized, which also combined with the preparation of boride catalysts [203]. The deposition reaction of sodium borohydride is similar to phosphorus. Nocera’s group [204] conducted a detailed study for the factors that the rate of electrodeposition. The sediment was produced by cyclic oxidation. Clearly, the surface morphology of amorphous films has merge into larger aggregates in the whole process of electrodeposition, and the subsequent discussion confirmed the effects of film properties on deposition conditions (mainly scan speed and range). Based on above studies, extensive work has developed for effective overall water splitting. Yang et al. [205] synthesized Co-Bi nanosheets array on Ti-mesh by electrodeposition and electrochemical turning. Benefit from the large geometric area, large number of active sites with amorphous leaks along with the strong interactions between B, O and Co, Co-Bi/Ti exhibited a remarkable activity for water oxidation, with an overpotential of 469 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 0.1 M K-Bi, showing the approximate activity with RuO2. It should be emphasized that the coatings obtained by one-step electrodeposition are boric compounds (M−Bi). Although has competitive OER activity, it should be noted that the obtained borate catalysts by electrodeposition are not adequate for HER or even the overall water splitting. 3.6 Heteroanion compound and heterostructure By means of one-step electrodeposition technique, we can realize not only the preparation of multi-metal alloy by hybrid plating solution, but also the compound of heteroanion (e.g., O, S, P, B and Se), which has been commonly acknowledged as a valid strategy to consummate electrocatalysis performance [136,206–209]. Meanwhile, the advanced computational analysis can be used for directional design of multi-component catalysts [210]. Kim et al. [206] reported an amorphous Co-P-B catalyst that in-situ grow on carbon paper (CP) by electrodeposition, and the highest HER intrinsic activity of Co59P20B21/CP catalyst was derived from the synergetic effect of B and P. KwangSup Eom’ group [211] prepared Co-Ni-P-B film on Cu foam via pre-deposition of Co-Ni pre and followed electroplating onto the precursor with the whole loading mass of 0.5 mg·cm−2. The two-step deposition technique made it possible for multi-element coordination and heterogeneous structure, and further analysis pointed out that endowed the film both higher active area and higher atomic ratio for B and P, thus elecated the HER activity. Chen et al. [212] reported an amorphous NiSPx microdendritic structure catalyst by one-step electrodeposition (Fig. 11 a). Roman spectra and XPS proved that the interaction between S and P together optimized the electronic environment around the Ni atom, and with small amount of Ni particles on nickel foam, it also exhibited excellent both HER and OER performance that only requires low overpotential of 46 mV and 231 mV at 10 mA·cm−2, respectively. As well as high current density working stability (2.38 V at 1000 mA·cm−2), this bifunctional catalyst had great significance for the application of high current density water H2 production technology fields. Besides, electrodeposition technique can be used to synthesize heterogeneous structures by itself or in conjunction with other techniques to prepare multifaceted catalysts [160,213–215]. Xu et al. [216] fabricated an ultrathin Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2 heterogeneous nanosheets on Ni foam by a one-step electrodeposition technique with large-potential and high-temperature. As shown in Fig. 11(b), SEM images showed the dense growth of Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2 on Ni foam, and the heterogeneous structure interface with ultrathin thickness was observed by TEM. UPS and XPS together proved the increase in the electron density that benefit for the suitable H* intermediates adsorption, and it has faster electron transfer efficiency by lowest work function. Based on these analysis, the Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2 demonstrated highly competitive HER activity with a very low overpotential of 142 mV to reach 200 mA cm−2 and small tafel slope of 49 mV dec−1. A prominent OER activity was confirmed by the overpotential of 280 mV at 100 mA cm−2, so the Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2 can serve as a bifunctional catalyst that only need a cell voltage of 1.49 V to reach 10 mA cm−2 with stability over 100 h. Xie and co-workers [217] synthesized a 3D core/shell Ni3N@Ni-Bi nanosheet array for overall water splitting, which successfully endowed the boride with bifunctional property. Some nonmetal-based compounds like PANI, modified graphene, etc., has been demonstrated to have synergistic catalytic effects in combination with metal-based materials, it also can be prepared by electrodeposition for the promoted HER activity [218,219]. Wang et al. [65] reported an in-situ strategy to synthesize PANI-coated Ru-Ni(OH)2 nanosheets on Ni foam. Via a simple electrodeposition, Ru-Ni(OH)2 nanosheets were completely coated by PANI. The followed PANI has been proved that enhanced electrical conductivity and stability, which also has strong electron interaction with Ru-Ni(OH)2 film, and thus the HER activity has been improved with long-term durable in wide pH range. Feng and co-workers [220] anchored PANI on the deposited Co(OH)2 nanosheets to obtain NS Co(OH)2@PANI HNSs/NF electrocatalyst (Fig. 12 ). With porous and core–shell structure, the strong electronic interactions of the mixed of amorphous PANI coating and Co(OH)2 with polycrystalline was investigated by XPS, Roman spectroscopy and DFT calculation, which also show a better electrocatalytic activity compared to Co(OH)2 by the optimized ΔG H* value, which showed in HER performance. Interestingly, Co(OH)2-PANI catalyst also possessed a good flexibility, its high catalytic performance was also remained even under mechanical distortion. Numerous laudable studies on HER and OER catalysts have focused on co-anion coordination and heterostructure assembly, and it is of promising value to utilize advanced electrodeposition technology to achieve precise regulation. 4 Conclusions and perspectives Electrodeposition has already adopted extensively as a surface treatment technique. In recent years, the century-old inheritance of technology, combined with the rapid development of advanced nanoscale design, has successfully bloomed new vitality. Especially, electrodeposition plays a vital role in the electrochemical hydrogen production strategy through which the synthesis of water splitting catalysts with excellent performance is achieved. Although many recent studies have won plentiful achievements around this hot spot, there is still a lack of comprehensive review in this field. Here we summarize electrodeposition technical characteristics in detail, and give a comprehensive overview of the key role in the synthesis of transition metal-based catalysts. Through a deeper understanding of electrodeposition characteristics in catalyst synthesis and the reaction mechanism of the catalyst in both HER and OER, we intend to obtain enlightenment on the preparation of catalyst as well as catalytic performance improvement. As a synthesis technology with high reaction rate and low energy consumption, the salient merits of electrodeposition are as follows: (1) The complex-transformed materials prepared by electrodeposition technology proves the universality of the synthesis strategy, such as various alloys and metal-based compounds, which facilitates the in-depth exploration of the catalytic performance for the functional materials. Electrodeposition not only has considerable preparation efficiency at ambient conditions, which can also be easily scaled up on large surface area substrates, with the good possibility of large-scale production. Although electrodeposition relies on a self-supporting substrate with good conductivity, it can fully meet the requirements of the catalyst synthesis process by fully utilizing the three-dimensional structure of the substrate itself and its strong stability.; (2) Flexible technical features is necessary for the precise design of material and accommodation to functional requirements. The properties of the product can be more enabled by appropriate deposited conditions, and the catalytic performance is sensitive to its fine-turning. More importantly, different from most synthetic methods, electrodeposition can ensure the stability and controllability of the structure and composition of the material in the macro preparation; (3) Many synthetics require multi-process collaboration, electrodeposition technology is relatively mild and can be better coordinated with other technologies makes the synthesis of nanomaterials more controllable, thereby greatly expands the scope of application of electrodeposition technology. For all to see, the technical upgrading of electrodeposition roundly brings about remarkable breakthroughs. In order to meet the following the trend of large-scale and effective hydrogen production, it is still necessary to continue to optimize the HER and OER performance to improve the working efficiency of the total water decomposition system. The intrinsic activity for HER and OER is related with electronic environment, which directly determines the adsorption properties of the intermediate (H* and OOH*), and it can be optimized by the electronegativity discrepancy between different elements and synergy between heterogeneous interface. From a catalyst perspective, future progress will undoubtedly tend to apply simpler strategies for the precise control to achieve both heteroatomic doping or heterostructure, as well as enlarge the active area through better nanostructures. Optimistically, tremendous reports witnessed that electrodeposition hold great potential in this field. Various catalysts have been synthesized via electrodeposition, not just for the better HER and OER kinetics but also can be competent under long working time and rigorous conditions, thus fully affirmed this technical route. As a promising technology for the synthesis of new catalysts in the future, electrodeposition also requires a targeted upgrade in the future development. One is recognized that electrodeposition method is sensitive to multiple factors in the process of composite material deposition. Therefore, the focus of future work is to explore the variation of parameters in multitudinous systems more accurately (around electricity input mode, electrolyte, substrate and template). Moreover, due to the complexity of the amorphous and composite deposited film, many reports lack of mechanism investigation into the catalytic behavior of electrodeposited materials, which makes them lack guidance for the follow-up work. Hence, more in-situ characterization and calculation support are urgently needed to reveal the behavior mechanism of catalyst participation in the reaction process as for the rational guidance to the catalyst design. Last but not the least, it is difficult to obtain the designed nanostructure and composition only through the electrodeposition process, and using assistive techniques or novel templates is still an effective strategy. So the key point is that exploring the advanced support technology and the integration of advanced template with electrodeposition technology to achieve more flexible structural and component manipulation, which will greatly accelerate the development of electrodeposition process. From a development perspective, future research work should attach importance on better combining electrodeposition strategy with the design principle of HER and OER catalysts, while reducing manufacturing costs and demonstrating green environmental characteristics are also necessary. To sum up, we hope that more targeted work will revolve around the synthesis of catalysts by electrodeposition and incorporates with in-depth analysis together to promote the development of electrolyzed water strategies, so as to achieve fast overtaking on high-efficiency hydrogen production. Ruopeng Li received his master’s degree in 2019 in the Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology (HIT), and currently he is a Ph.D. candidate under Professor Peixia Yang there. His main research focuses on the efficient clean energy conversion system, including the synthesis of advanced transition metal-based catalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and biomass electro-oxidation reaction (BEOR). Yun Li obtained her bachelor degree in 2019 in the department of materials chemistry, Harbin Institute of Technology University, and is presently pursuing her B.E. there. Her research interests include nanomaterials and energy electrocatalysis, including transition metal phosphides, hierarchical hybrids, OER and HER catalysts. Peixia Yang is currently a professor of School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, China. She obtained his Ph.D. Degree in Chemical Engineering from HIT of Chemical Technology in 2006. During 2013.03-2014.03, she worked as a visiting scholar at St. Petersburg State University, Russia. Currently she has interests in non-precious metal-based catalysts for energy conversion devices, polymer solid electrolyte and functional materials synthesized by advanced electrodeposition technology. She is author of roughly 80 journal articles. Dan Wang received her B.S. degree from Hebei University of Technology in 2016. She is currently pursing for her Ph.D. degree in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering under the supervision of Prof. Pei-xia Yang at Harbin Institute of Technology. Her research is focused the on the synthesis and characterization of transition metal and nitrogen doped carbon-based materials as highly efficient catalysts for Oxygen reduction in Zn-air batteries and fuel cells. Hao Xu graduated from Dalian University of Technology (DUT) with a Bachelor’s degree in 2018. Currently, he is a Ph. D. candidate in Harbin Institute of Technology (HIT). His current research is focused on the preparation of single atom M-N-C catalysts for ORR and their application in the Zn-air batteries. Bo Wang is an Associate Prof. in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Harbin Institute of Technology (HIT), China. He received his B. E. and Ph.D. degree at HIT in 2009 and 2015, respectively. He was a joint-training Ph.D. at The University of Queensland, Australia, in 2012-2014. He joined Prof. Rodney. S. Ruoff’s lab as a postdoctoral fellow in the Center for Multidimensional Carbon Materials (CMCM), Institute for Basic Science (IBS) in Korea, in 2017-2018. His current research interests are associated with electrochemical energy storage and conversion, electrocatalysis, etc. Fan Meng received his bachelor degree in the School of Chemical Engineering and Chemistry from Harbin Institute of Technology, China in 2020, and is currently pursuing his master degree there. His research interests focus on electrocatalysis and electrodeposition, including simulation calculation, the design of OER and ORR catalysts. Jinqiu Zhang graduated with a Ph.D. degree in Chemical Engineering and Technology from Harbin Institute of Technology (HIT) in 2009. She works at the Department of Electrochemical Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of HIT. Her research interests include electrodeposition of functional materials, catalysts for Lithium air batteries, catalysts for CO2 reduction reactions. Dr Zhang is the author of around 40 publications in the field of electrochemistry and several book chapters. Maozhong An obtained his Ph.D. in Material Chemistry and Physics from Harbin Institute of Technology (HIT) in 1999. He is currently a full professor the Department of Electrochemical Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of HIT. He has been committed to researching the application of advanced electrodeposition technology, including electrodeposition alloy technology and mechanism, functional coating, electrodeposition of new nano materials and research in the field of electronic electroplating.

coredata.dc:description: Developing lower-cost and higher-effective catalyst to support hydrogen (H2) production by electrochemical water-splitting has been recognized as a preferred strategy to drive the clean energy utilization. As a credible technology for the synthesis of functional materials, electrodeposition has attracted widespread attention, especially suitable for non-noble transition metal-based catalysts (TMCs). Recently, lots of researchers have been devoted to this hot research direction with plentiful achievements, however, a comprehensive review towards this area is still missing. Hence, we summarize the past research progress, presents the technical characteristics of electrodeposition from the viewpoint of fundamental theory and influence factors for the electrochemical deposition behavior, and introduce its application in various of TMCs with versatile nanostructures and compositions. Except a deeper and more comprehensive cognition of electrodeposition, we further discuss the catalyst's optimized hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) performance as well as overall water splitting that combined with the synthetic process. Finally, we conclude the technical advantages towards electrodeposition, propose challenge and future research directions in this promising field. This timely review aims to promote a deeper understanding of effective catalysts obtained via electrodeposition strategy, and provide new guidance for the design and synthesis of future catalysts for hydrogen production.
